http://edamontology.org/operation_0558.label: Phylogenetic tree annotation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0558.description: Annotate a phylogenetic tree with terms from a controlled vocabulary.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2487.label: Protein structure comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_2487.description: Compare protein tertiary structures.|Methods might identify structural neighbors, find structural similarities or define a structural core.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0527.label: Sequence tag mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0527.description: Make sequence tag to gene assignments (tag mapping) of SAGE, MPSS and SBS data.|Sequence tag mapping assigns experimentally obtained sequence tags to known transcripts or annotate potential virtual sequence tags in a genome.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3504.label: Variant pattern analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3504.description: Identify and map patterns of genomic variations.|Methods often utilise a database of aligned reads.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2929.label: Protein fragment weight comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_2929.description: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein (or fragments) and compare it to another protein or reference data. Generally used for protein identification.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0285.label: Codon usage table comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_0285.description: Compare two or more codon usage tables.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3083.label: Pathway or network visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3083.description: Render (visualise) a biological pathway or network.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3209.label: Genome comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_3209.description: Compare the sequence or features of two or more genomes, for example, to find matching regions.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3791.label: Collapsing methods
http://edamontology.org/operation_3791.description: A method whereby data on several variants are "collapsed" into a single covariate based on regions such as genes.|Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) analyse a genome-wide set of genetic variants in different individuals to see if any variant is associated with a trait. Traditional association techniques can lack the power to detect the significance of rare variants individually, or measure their compound effect (rare variant burden).  "Collapsing methods" were developed to overcome these problems.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3435.label: Standardisation and normalisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3435.description: Standardize or normalize data by some statistical method.| In the simplest normalisation means adjusting values measured on different scales to a common scale (often between 0.0 and 1.0), but can refer to more sophisticated adjustment whereby entire probability distributions of adjusted values are brought into alignment. Standardisation typically refers to an operation whereby a range of values are standardised to measure how many standard deviations a value is from its mean.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0560.label: DNA vaccine design
http://edamontology.org/operation_0560.description: Predict or optimise DNA to elicit (via DNA vaccination) an immunological response.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0446.label: Exonic splicing enhancer prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0446.description: Identify or predict exonic splicing enhancers (ESE) in exons.|An exonic splicing enhancer (ESE) is 6-base DNA sequence motif in an exon that enhances or directs splicing of pre-mRNA or hetero-nuclear RNA (hnRNA) into mRNA.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0405.label: Protein hydrophobic region calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0405.description: Calculate hydrophobic or hydrophilic / charged regions of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3658.label: Statistical inference
http://edamontology.org/operation_3658.description: Analyse data in order to deduce properties of an underlying distribution or population.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1836.label: Residue bump detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_1836.description: Detect 'bumps' between residues in a structure, i.e. those with pairs of atoms whose Van der Waals' radii interpenetrate more than a defined distance.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0286.label: Codon usage analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0286.description: Process (read and / or write) codon usage data, e.g. analyse codon usage tables or codon usage in molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0406.label: Protein aliphatic index calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0406.description: Calculate aliphatic index (relative volume occupied by aliphatic side chains) of a protein.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3559.label: Ontology visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3559.description: Visualise, format or render data from an ontology, typically a tree of terms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0396.label: Ramachandran plot calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0396.description: Calculate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2423.label: Prediction and recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_2423.description: Predict, recognise, detect or identify some properties of a biomolecule.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3352.label: Ontology comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_3352.description: Compare two or more ontologies, e.g. identify differences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0364.label: Random sequence generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0364.description: Generate a random sequence, for example, with a specific character composition.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2429.label: Mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_2429.description: Map properties to positions on an biological entity (typically a molecular sequence or structure), or assemble such an entity from constituent parts.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3237.label: Primer removal
http://edamontology.org/operation_3237.description: Remove forward and/or reverse primers from nucleic acid sequences (typically PCR products).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0549.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (AI methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0549.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by using artificial-intelligence methods, for example genetic algorithms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3447.label: Diffraction data reduction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3447.description: Processing of diffraction data into a corrected, ordered, and simplified form.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0302.label: Protein threading
http://edamontology.org/operation_0302.description: Align molecular sequence to structure in 3D space (threading).|Use this concept for methods that evaluate sequence-structure compatibility by assessing residue interactions in 3D. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3349.label: Bibliography generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3349.description: Construct a bibliography from the scientific literature.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0430.label: CpG island and isochore detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0430.description: Find CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence or isochores in genome sequences.|An isochore is long region (> 3 KB) of DNA with very uniform GC content, in contrast to the rest of the genome. Isochores tend tends to have more genes, higher local melting or denaturation temperatures, and different flexibility. Methods might calculate fractional GC content or variation of GC content, predict methylation status of CpG islands etc. This includes methods that visualise CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence, for example plot isochores in a genome sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0474.label: Protein structure prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0474.description: Predict tertiary structure (backbone and side-chain conformation) of protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3560.label: Maximum occurence analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3560.description: A method for making numerical assessments about the maximum percent of time that a conformer of a flexible macromolecule can exist and still be compatible with the experimental data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2871.label: Sequence tagged site (STS) mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_2871.description: Generate a physical DNA map (sequence map) from analysis of sequence tagged sites (STS).|An STS is a short subsequence of known sequence and location that occurs only once in the chromosome or genome that is being mapped. Sources of STSs include 1. expressed sequence tags (ESTs), simple sequence length polymorphisms (SSLPs), and random genomic sequences from cloned genomic DNA or database sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0437.label: SECIS element prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0437.description: Predict selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in a DNA sequence.|SECIS elements are around 60 nucleotides in length with a stem-loop structure directs the cell to translate UGA codons as selenocysteines.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3503.label: Incident curve plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3503.description: Plot an incident curve such as a survival curve, death curve, mortality curve.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0236.label: Sequence composition calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0236.description: Calculate character or word composition or frequency of a molecular sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2520.label: DNA mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_2520.description: Generate a map of a DNA sequence annotated with positional or non-positional features of some type.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3180.label: Sequence assembly validation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3180.description: Evaluate a DNA sequence assembly, typically for purposes of quality control.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1830.label: Free cysteine detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_1830.description: Detect free cysteines in a protein structure.|A free cysteine is neither involved in a cysteine bridge, nor functions as a ligand to a metal.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3183.label: Localised reassembly
http://edamontology.org/operation_3183.description: Reconstruction of a sequence assembly in a localised area.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2424.label: Comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_2424.description: Compare two or more things to identify similarities.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0526.label: EST assembly
http://edamontology.org/operation_0526.description: Sequence assembly for EST sequences (transcribed mRNA).|Assemblers must handle (or be complicated by) alternative splicing, trans-splicing, single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP), recoding, and post-transcriptional modification.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3283.label: Anonymisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3283.description: Process data in such a way that makes it hard to trace to the person which the data concerns.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2997.label: Protein comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_2997.description: Compare two or more proteins (or some aspect) to identify similarities.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0331.label: Protein modelling (mutation)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0331.description: Predict the effect of point mutation on a protein structure, in terms of strucural effects and protein folding, stability and function.|This includes 1) rotamer likelihood prediction: the prediction of rotamer likelihoods for all 20 amino acid types at each position in a protein structure, where output typically includes, for each residue position, the likelihoods for the 20 amino acid types with estimated reliability of the 20 likelihoods.  2) Protein SNP mapping, which maps and modesl the effects of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on protein structure(s).  Methods might predict silent or pathological mutations.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0303.label: Protein fold recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_0303.description: Recognize (predict and identify) known protein structural domains or folds in protein sequence(s) which (typically) are not accompanied by any significant sequence similarity to know structures.|Methods use some type of mapping between sequence and fold, for example secondary structure prediction and alignment, profile comparison, sequence properties, homologous sequence search, kernel machines etc. Domains and folds might be taken from SCOP or CATH.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0573.label: Map drawing
http://edamontology.org/operation_0573.description: Draw or visualise a DNA map.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2928.label: Alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_2928.description: Compare two or more entities, typically the sequence or structure (or derivatives) of macromolecules, to identify equivalent subunits.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2233.label: Representative sequence identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_2233.description: Identify a representative sequence from a set of sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0428.label: PolyA signal detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0428.description: Detect polyA signals in nucleotide sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2485.label: Helical wheel drawing
http://edamontology.org/operation_2485.description: Render a helical wheel representation of protein secondary structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3501.label: Enrichment analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3501.description: Analysis of a set of objects, such as genes, annotated with given categories, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain categories within the studied set of objects is revealed.|Categories from a relevant ontology can be used. The input is typically a set of genes or other biological objects, possibly represented by their identifiers, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of categories, each associated with a statistical metric of over-/under-representation within the studied data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3278.label: Document similarity calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3278.description: Calculate similarity between 2 or more documents.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2422.label: Data retrieval
http://edamontology.org/operation_2422.description: Retrieve an entry (or part of an entry) from a data resource that matches a supplied query. This might include some primary data and annotation. The query is a data identifier or other indexed term. For example, retrieve a sequence record with the specified accession number, or matching supplied keywords.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3357.label: Format detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_3357.description: Recognition of which format the given data is in.|'Format recognition' is not a bioinformatics-specific operation, but of great relevance in bioinformatics. Should be removed from EDAM if/when captured satisfactorily in a suitable domain-generic ontology.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1781.label: Gene regulatory network analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_1781.description: Analyse a known network of gene regulation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3643.label: Tag-based peptide identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3643.description: Peptide sequence tags are used as piece of information about a peptide obtained by tandem mass spectrometry.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3469.label: RNA structure covariance model generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3469.description: Compute the covariance model for (a family of) RNA secondary structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0248.label: Residue interaction calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0248.description: Calculate or extract inter-atomic, inter-residue or residue-atom contacts, distances and interactions in protein structure(s).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3741.label: Differential protein expression analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3741.description: The analysis, using proteomics techniques, to identify proteins whose encoding genes are differentially expressed under a given experimental setup.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3204.label: Methylation analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3204.description: Determine cytosine methylation states in nucleic acid sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0390.label: Protein peeling
http://edamontology.org/operation_0390.description: Decompose a structure into compact or globular fragments (protein peeling).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0432.label: Nucleosome formation or exclusion sequence prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0432.description: Identify or predict nucleosome exclusion sequences (nucleosome free regions) in DNA.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1834.label: Protein-metal contact calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_1834.description: Calculate protein residue contacts with metal in a structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3647.label: Blind peptide database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_3647.description: Peptide database search for identification of known and unknown PTMs looking for mass difference mismatches.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0321.label: Protein model validation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0321.description: Evaluate the quality or correctness a protein three-dimensional model.|This includes methods that calculate poor quality residues. The scoring function to identify poor quality residues may consider residues with bad atoms or atoms with high B-factor, residues in the N- or C-terminal position, adjacent to an unstructured residue, non-canonical residues, glycine and proline (or adjacent to these such residues).|Model validation might involve checks for atomic packing, steric clashes (bumps), volume irregularities, agreement with electron density maps, number of amino acid residues, percentage of residues with missing or bad atoms, irregular Ramachandran Z-scores, irregular Chi-1 / Chi-2 normality scores, RMS-Z score on bonds and angles etc.|The PDB file format has had difficulties, inconsistencies and errors. Corrections can include identifying a meaningful sequence, removal of alternate atoms, correction of nomenclature problems, removal of incomplete residues and spurious waters, addition or removal of water, modelling of missing side chains, optimisation of cysteine bonds, regularisation of bond lengths, bond angles and planarities etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3763.label: Service invocation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3763.description: An operation supporting the calling (invocation) of other tools and services.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0370.label: Restriction site creation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0370.description: Create (or remove) restriction sites in sequences, for example using silent mutations.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0475.label: Nucleic acid structure prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0475.description: Predict structure of DNA or RNA.|Methods might identify thermodynamically stable or evolutionarily conserved structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2944.label: Physical mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_2944.description: Generate a physical (sequence) map of a DNA sequence showing the physical distance (base pairs) between features or landmarks such as restriction sites, cloned DNA fragments, genes and other genetic markers.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2426.label: Modelling and simulation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2426.description: Model or simulate some biological entity or system, typically using mathematical techniques including  dynamical systems, statistical models, differential equations, and game theoretic models.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3792.label: miRNA expression analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3792.description: The analysis of microRNAs (miRNAs) : short, highly conserved small noncoding RNA molecules that are naturally occurring plant and animal genomes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3563.label: RNA-seq read count analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3563.description: Analyze read counts from RNA-seq experiments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0398.label: Protein molecular weight calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0398.description: Calculate the molecular weight of a protein sequence or fragments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3641.label: TMT-tag
http://edamontology.org/operation_3641.description: Quantification analysis using the Thermo Fisher tandem mass tag labelling workflow.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0476.label: Ab initio structure prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0476.description: Predict tertiary structure of protein sequence(s) without homologs of known structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0327.label: Phylogenetic footprinting / shadowing
http://edamontology.org/operation_0327.description: Infer a phylogenetic tree by comparing orthologous sequences in different species, particularly many closely related species (phylogenetic shadowing).|A phylogenetic 'shadow' represents the additive differences between individual sequences. By masking or 'shadowing' variable positions a conserved sequence is produced with few or none of the variations, which is then compared to the sequences of interest to identify significant regions of conservation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2513.label: Sequence generation (nucleic acid)
http://edamontology.org/operation_2513.description: Generate a nucleic acid sequence by some means.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2935.label: Clustering profile plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_2935.description: Visualise clustered quantitative data as set of different profiles, where each profile is plotted versus different entities or samples on the X-axis.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0525.label: Genome assembly
http://edamontology.org/operation_0525.description: The process of assembling many short DNA sequences together such thay they represent the original chromosomes from which the DNA originated.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3803.label: Natural product identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3803.description: Mass spectra identification of compounds that are produced by living systems. Including polyketides, terpenoids, phenylpropanoids, alkaloids and antibiotics.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2995.label: Sequence classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_2995.description: Assign molecular sequence(s) to a group or category.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0291.label: Sequence clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_0291.description: Build clusters of similar sequences, typically using scores from pair-wise alignment or other comparison of the sequences.|The clusters may be output or used internally for some other purpose.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1843.label: Residue packing validation
http://edamontology.org/operation_1843.description: Identify poorly packed residues in protein structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0533.label: Gene to pathway mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0533.description: Map a gene expression profile to known biological pathways, for example, to identify or reconstruct a pathway.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1829.label: Cysteine bridge detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_1829.description: Detect cysteine bridges (from coordinate data) in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3730.label: Cross-assembly
http://edamontology.org/operation_3730.description: Construction of a single sequence assembly of all reads from different samples, typically as part of a comparative metagenomic analysis.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3222.label: Peak calling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3222.description: Identify putative protein-binding regions in a genome sequence from analysis of Chip-sequencing data or ChIP-on-chip data.|Chip-sequencing combines chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) with massively parallel DNA sequencing to generate a set of reads, which are aligned to a genome sequence.  The enriched areas contain the binding sites of DNA-associated proteins.  For example, a transcription factor binding site. ChIP-on-chip in contrast combines chromatin immunoprecipitation ('ChIP') with microarray ('chip').  "Peak-pair calling" is similar to "Peak calling" in the context of ChIP-exo.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2425.label: Optimisation and refinement
http://edamontology.org/operation_2425.description: Refine or optimise some data model.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2930.label: Protein property comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_2930.description: Compare the physicochemical properties of two or more proteins (or reference data).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3666.label: Molecular surface comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_3666.description: Compare two or more molecular surfaces.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0478.label: Molecular docking
http://edamontology.org/operation_0478.description: Model the structure of a protein in complex with a small molecule or another macromolecule.|This includes protein-protein interactions, protein-nucleic acid, protein-ligand binding etc. Methods might predict whether the molecules are likely to bind in vivo, their conformation when bound, the strength of the interaction, possible mutations to achieve bonding and so on.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3457.label: Single particle analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3457.description: An image processing technique that combines and analyze multiple images of a particulate sample, in order to produce an image with clearer features that are more easily interpreted.|Single particle analysis is used to improve the information that can be obtained by relatively low resolution techniques, , e.g. an image of a protein or virus from transmission electron microscopy (TEM).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3778.label: Text annotation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3778.description: Text annotation is the operation of adding notes, data and metadata, recognised entities and concepts, and their relations to a text (such as a scientific article).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3223.label: Differential gene expression analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3223.description: Identify from molecular sequence analysis (typically from analysis of microarray or RNA-seq data) genes whose expression levels are significantly different between two sample groups.|Differential gene expression analysis is used, for example, to identify which genes are up-regulated (increased expression) or down-regulated (decreased expression) between a group treated with a drug and a control groups.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0306.label: Text mining
http://edamontology.org/operation_0306.description: Process and analyse text (typically scientific literature) to extract information from it.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0456.label: Nucleic acid melting profile plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0456.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting profile.|A melting profile is used to visualise and analyse partly melted DNA conformations.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2486.label: Topology diagram drawing
http://edamontology.org/operation_2486.description: Render a topology diagram of protein secondary structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0487.label: Haplotype mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0487.description: Infer haplotypes, either alleles at multiple loci that are transmitted together on the same chromosome, or a set of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on a single chromatid that are statistically associated.|Haplotype inference can help in population genetic studies and the identification of complex disease genes, , and is typically based on aligned single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) fragments. Haplotype comparison is a useful way to characterize the genetic variation between individuals. An individual's haplotype describes which nucleotide base occurs at each position for a set of common SNPs. Tools might use combinatorial functions (for example parsimony) or a likelihood function or model with optimisation such as minimum error correction (MEC) model, expectation-maximisation algorithm (EM), genetic algorithm or Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3761.label: Service discovery
http://edamontology.org/operation_3761.description: An operation supporting the browsing or discovery of other tools and services.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0417.label: Post-translation modification site prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0417.description: Predict post-translation modification sites in protein sequences.|Methods might predict sites of methylation, N-terminal myristoylation, N-terminal acetylation, sumoylation, palmitoylation, phosphorylation, sulfation, glycosylation, glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) modification sites (GPI lipid anchor signals) etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3202.label: Polymorphism detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_3202.description: Detect mutations in multiple DNA sequences, for example, from the alignment and comparison of the fluorescent traces produced by DNA sequencing hardware.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0244.label: Protein flexibility and motion analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0244.description: Analyse flexibility and motion in protein structure.|Use this concept for analysis of flexible and rigid residues, local chain deformability, regions undergoing conformational change, molecular vibrations or fluctuational dynamics, domain motions or other large-scale structural transitions in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3199.label: Split read mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_3199.description: A varient of oligonucleotide mapping where a read is mapped to two separate locations because of possible structural variation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0252.label: Peptide immunogenicity prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0252.description: Predict antigenicity, allergenicity / immunogenicity, allergic cross-reactivity etc of peptides and proteins.|This includes methods that generate a graphical rendering of antigenicity of a protein, such as a Hopp and Woods plot.|This is usually done in the development of peptide-specific antibodies or multi-epitope vaccines. Methods might use sequence data (for example motifs) and / or structural data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0268.label: Protein super-secondary structure prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0268.description: Predict super-secondary structure of protein sequence(s).|Super-secondary structures include leucine zippers, coiled coils, Helix-Turn-Helix etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0287.label: Base position variability plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0287.description: Identify and plot third base position variability in a nucleotide sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0266.label: Vector sequence detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0266.description: Detect vector sequences in nucleotide sequence, typically by comparison to a set of known vector sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3228.label: Structural variation detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_3228.description: Detect large regions in a genome subject to copy-number variation, or other structural variations in genome(s).|Methods might involve analysis of whole-genome array comparative genome hybridisation or single-nucleotide polymorphism arrays, paired-end mapping of sequencing data, or from analysis of short reads from new sequencing technologies.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0443.label: trans-regulatory element prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0443.description: Identify or predict functional RNA sequences with a gene regulatory role (trans-regulatory elements) or targets.|Trans-regulatory elements regulate genes distant from the gene from which they were transcribed.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3660.label: Metabolic network modelling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3660.description: Model a metabolic network, for example, to reconstruct pathways or to simulate metabolism.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0284.label: Codon usage table generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0284.description: Calculate codon usage statistics and create a codon usage table.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0490.label: Dot plot plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0490.description: Render a representation of a distribution that consists of group of data points plotted on a simple scale.|Dot plots are useful when having not too many (e.g. 20) data points for each category. Example: draw a dotplot of sequence similarities identified from word-matching or character comparison.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0387.label: Molecular surface calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0387.description: Calculate the molecular surface area in proteins and other macromolecules.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0282.label: Genetic mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0282.description: Generate a genetic (linkage) map of a DNA sequence (typically a chromosome) showing the relative positions of genetic markers based on estimation of non-physical distances.|Mapping involves ordering genetic loci along a chromosome and estimating the physical distance between loci. A genetic map shows the relative (not physical) position of known genes and genetic markers.|This includes mapping of the genetic architecture of dynamic complex traits (functional mapping), e.g. by characterisation of the underlying quantitative trait loci (QTLs) or nucleotides (QTNs).

http://edamontology.org/operation_1778.label: Protein function comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_1778.description: Compare the functional properties of two or more proteins.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3628.label: Chromatographic alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_3628.description: Align multiple data sets using information from chromatography and/or peptide identification, from mass spectrometry experiments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3215.label: Peak detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_3215.description: Identify peaks in a spectrum from a mass spectrometry, NMR, or some other spectrum-generating experiment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0334.label: Enzyme kinetics calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0334.description: Calculate Km, Vmax and derived data for an enzyme reaction.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0253.label: Sequence feature detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0253.description: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in molecular sequences such as key functional sites or regions.|Look at "Protein feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_3092) and "Nucleic acid feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_0415) in case more specific terms are needed.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3450.label: Neurite measurement
http://edamontology.org/operation_3450.description: Measurement of neurites; projections (axons or dendrites) from the cell body of a neuron, from analysis of neuron images.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0399.label: Protein extinction coefficient calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0399.description: Predict extinction coefficients or optical density of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0496.label: Global alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0496.description: Globally align two or more molecular sequences.|Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire length of the sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0567.label: Phylogenetic tree visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0567.description: Render or visualise a phylogenetic tree.

synonyms: Gene expression quantitative trait loci profiling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3232.label: Gene expression QTL analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3232.description: Combine classical quantitative trait loci (QTL) analysis with gene expression profiling, for example, to describe describe cis- and trans-controlling elements for the expression of phenotype associated genes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3219.label: Read pre-processing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3219.description: Pre-process sequence reads to ensure (or improve) quality and reliability.|For example process paired end reads to trim low quality ends remove short sequences, identify sequence inserts, detect chimeric reads, or remove low quality sequnces including vector, adaptor, low complexity and contaminant sequences. Sequences might come from genomic DNA library, EST libraries, SSH library and so on.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0531.label: Heat map generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0531.description: Generate a heat map of expression data from e.g. microarray data.|The heat map usually uses a coloring scheme to represent expression values. They can show how quantitative measurements were influenced by experimental conditions.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3625.label: Relation extraction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3625.description: Identify semantic relations among entities and concepts within a text, using text mining techniques.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3797.label: Rarefaction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3797.description: The calculation of species richness for a number of individual samples, based on plots of the number of species as a function of the number of samples (rarefaction curves).

http://edamontology.org/operation_2940.label: Scatter plot plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_2940.description: Render a graph in which the values of two variables are plotted along two axes; the pattern of the points reveals any correlation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3566.label: Simulated gene expression data generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3566.description: Simulate gene expression data, e.g. for purposes of benchmarking.

synonyms: Phylogenetic tree construction (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0547.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (maximum likelihood and Bayesian methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0547.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by relating sequence data to a hypothetical tree topology using a model of sequence evolution.|Maximum likelihood methods search for a tree that maximizes a likelihood function, i.e. that is most likely given the data and model. Bayesian analysis estimate the probability of tree for branch lengths and topology, typically using a Monte Carlo algorithm.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2514.label: Sequence generation (protein)
http://edamontology.org/operation_2514.description: Generate a protein sequence by some means.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0492.label: Multiple sequence alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0492.description: Align more than two molecular sequences.|This includes methods that use an existing alignment, for example to incorporate sequences into an alignment, or combine several multiple alignments into a single, improved alignment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0339.label: Structure database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_0339.description: Search a tertiary structure database, typically by sequence and/or structure comparison, or some other means, and retrieve structures and associated data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0247.label: Protein architecture analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0247.description: Analyse the architecture (spatial arrangement of secondary structure) of protein structure(s).

http://edamontology.org/operation_2990.label: Classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_2990.description: Assign molecular sequences, structures or other biological data to a specific group or category according to qualities it shares with that group or category.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2495.label: Gene expression analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2495.description: The application of bioinformatics methods to the study of gene products, typically by processing gene expression data or profiles, interpreting them in functional terms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2475.label: Protein architecture recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_2475.description: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.|Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0542.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from gene frequencies)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0542.description: Phylogenetic tree construction from gene frequency data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0441.label: cis-regulatory element prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0441.description: Identify, predict or analyse cis-regulatory elements  in DNA sequences (TATA box, Pribnow box, SOS box, CAAT box, CCAAT box, operator etc.) or in RNA sequences (e.g. riboswitches).|Cis-regulatory elements (cis-elements) regulate the expression of genes located on the same strand from which the element was transcribed. Cis-elements are found in the 5' promoter region of the gene, in an intron, or in the 3' untranslated region. Cis-elements are often binding sites of one or more trans-acting factors. They also occur in RNA sequences, e.g. a riboswitch is a region of an mRNA molecule that bind a small target molecule that regulates the gene's activity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3195.label: Sequencing error detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_3195.description: Detect errors in DNA sequences generated from sequencing projects).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0509.label: Local structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0509.description: Locally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.|Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity, common substructures etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0433.label: Splice site prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0433.description: Identify, predict or analyse splice sites in nucleotide sequences.|Methods might require a pre-mRNA or genomic DNA sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0439.label: Translation initiation site prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0439.description: Predict translation initiation sites, possibly by searching a database of sites.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0450.label: Chimera detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0450.description: Detects chimeric sequences (chimeras) from a sequence alignment.|A chimera includes regions from two or more phylogenetically distinct sequences. They are usually artifacts of PCR and are thought to occur when a prematurely terminated amplicon reanneals to another DNA strand and is subsequently copied to completion in later PCR cycles.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3632.label: Isotopic distributions calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3632.description: Calculate the isotope distribution of a given chemical species.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2238.label: Statistical calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2238.description: Perform a statistical data operation of some type, e.g. calibration or validation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0455.label: Nucleic acid thermodynamic property calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0455.description: Calculate a thermodynamic property of DNA or DNA/RNA, such as melting temperature, enthalpy and entropy.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3459.label: Functional clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3459.description: Clustering of molecular sequences on the basis of their function, typically using information from an ontology of gene function, or some other measure of functional phenotype.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3185.label: Base-calling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3185.description: Identify base (nucleobase) sequence from a fluorescence 'trace' data generated by an automated DNA sequencer.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2436.label: Gene-set enrichment analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2436.description: Analysis of a set of genes, corresponding e.g. to a gene expression profile, annotated with Gene Ontology (GO) concepts, where eventual over-/under-representation of certain GO concept within the studied set of genes is revealed.|The Gene Ontology (GO) is typically used, the input is a set of Gene IDs, and the output of the analysis is typically a ranked list of GO concepts, each associated with a p-value.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2008.label: siRNA duplex prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_2008.description: Identify or predict siRNA duplexes in RNA.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3438.label: Calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3438.description: Mathematical determination of the value of something, typically a properly of a  molecule.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3280.label: Named-entity and concept recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_3280.description: Recognise named entities, ontology concepts, tags, events, and dictionary terms within documents.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2949.label: Protein interaction analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2949.description: Analyse known protein-protein, protein-DNA/RNA or protein-ligand interactions.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0224.label: Query and retrieval
http://edamontology.org/operation_0224.description: Search or query a data resource and retrieve entries and / or annotation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1844.label: Protein geometry validation
http://edamontology.org/operation_1844.description: Validate protein geometry, for example bond lengths, bond angles, torsion angles, chiralities, planaraties etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3216.label: Scaffolding
http://edamontology.org/operation_3216.description: Link together a non-contiguous series of genomic sequences into a scaffold, consisting of sequences separated by gaps of known length.  The sequences that are linked are typically typically contigs; contiguous sequences corresponding to read overlaps.|Scaffold may be positioned along a chromosome physical map to create a "golden path".

http://edamontology.org/operation_2454.label: Gene prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_2454.description: Detect, predict and identify genes or components of genes in DNA sequences, including promoters, coding regions, splice sites, etc. |Methods for gene prediction might be ab initio, based on phylogenetic comparisons, use motifs, sequence features, support vector machine, alignment etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3633.label: Retention time prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3633.description: Prediction of retention time in a mass spectrometry experiment based on compositional and structural properties of the separated species.

synonyms: Expression data tree or dendrogram rendering
http://edamontology.org/operation_2938.label: Dendrogram visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2938.description: Visualise clustered expression data using a tree diagram.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0410.label: Protein crystallizability prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0410.description: Predict crystallizability of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0485.label: Radiation Hybrid Mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0485.description: Generate a physical (radiation hybrid) map of genetic markers in a DNA sequence using provided radiation hybrid (RH) scores for one or more markers.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3766.label: Weighted correlation network analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3766.description: A data mining method typically used for studying biological networks based on pairwise correlations between variables.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2963.label: Codon usage bias plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_2963.description: Generate a codon usage bias plot.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0272.label: Residue interaction prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0272.description: Predict contacts, non-covalent interactions and distance (constraints) between amino acids in protein sequences.|Methods usually involve multiple sequence alignment analysis.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3649.label: Target-Decoy
http://edamontology.org/operation_3649.description: Statistical estimation of false discovery rate from score distribution for peptide-spectrum-matches, following a peptide database search, and by comparison to search results with a database containing incorrect information.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2476.label: Molecular dynamics
http://edamontology.org/operation_2476.description: Simulate molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0278.label: RNA secondary structure prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0278.description: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).|Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0548.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (quartet methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0548.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing four-taxon trees (4-trees) and searching for the phylogeny that matches most closely.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3562.label: Network simulation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3562.description: Simulate the bevaviour of a biological pathway or network.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0540.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from molecular sequences)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0540.description: Phylogenetic tree construction from molecular sequences.|Methods typically compare multiple molecular sequence and estimate evolutionary distances and relationships to infer gene families or make functional predictions.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0366.label: Protein sequence cleavage
http://edamontology.org/operation_0366.description: Cleave a protein sequence into peptide fragments (corresponding to enzymatic or chemical cleavage).

http://edamontology.org/operation_2451.label: Sequence comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_2451.description: Compare two or more molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3455.label: Molecular replacement
http://edamontology.org/operation_3455.description: A technique used to construct an atomic model of an unknown structure from diffraction data, based upon an atomic model of a known structure, either a related protein or the same protein from a different crystal form.|The technique solves the phase problem, i.e. retrieve information concern phases of the structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0256.label: Sequence feature comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_0256.description: Compare the feature tables of two or more molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3429.label: Generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3429.description: Construct some data entity.|For non-analytical operations, see the 'Processing' branch.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3233.label: Copy number estimation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3233.description: Estimate the number of copies of loci of particular gene(s) in DNA sequences typically from gene-expression profiling technology based on microarray hybridisation-based experiments. For example, estimate copy number (or marker dosage) of a dominant marker in samples from polyploid plant cells or tissues, or chromosomal gains and losses in tumors.|Methods typically implement some statistical model for hypothesis testing, and methods estimate total copy number, i.e. do not distinguish the two inherited chromosomes quantities (specific copy number).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3767.label: Protein identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3767.description: Identification of protein, for example from one or more peptide identifications by tandem mass spectrometry.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0379.label: Repeat sequence detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0379.description: Find (and possibly render) short repetitive subsequences (repeat sequences) in (typically nucleotide) sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0571.label: Expression data visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0571.description: Visualise microarray or other expression data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0459.label: Nucleic acid probability profile plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0459.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA probability profile.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0545.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (parsimony methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0545.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing a sequence alignment and searching for the tree with the fewest number of character-state changes from the alignment.|This includes evolutionary parsimony (invariants) methods.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0440.label: Promoter prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0440.description: Identify or predict whole promoters or promoter elements (transcription start sites, RNA polymerase binding site, transcription factor binding sites, promoter enhancers etc) in DNA sequences.|Methods might recognize CG content, CpG islands, splice sites, polyA signals etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3627.label: Mass spectra calibration
http://edamontology.org/operation_3627.description: Re-adjust the output of mass spectrometry experiments with shifted ppm values.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3279.label: Document clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3279.description: Cluster (group) documents on the basis of their calculated similarity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0578.label: Plasmid map drawing
http://edamontology.org/operation_0578.description: Draw a circular maps of DNA, for example a plasmid map.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3809.label: Differentially-methylated region identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3809.description: Identify and assess specific genes or regulatory regions of interest that are differentially methylated.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0491.label: Pairwise sequence alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0491.description: Align exactly two molecular sequences.|Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3760.label: Service management
http://edamontology.org/operation_3760.description: Operations concerning the handling and use of other tools.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3637.label: Spectral counting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3637.description: Calculate number of identified MS2 spectra as approximation of peptide / protein quantity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2510.label: DNA back-translation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2510.description: Back-translate a protein sequence into DNA.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2964.label: Codon usage fraction calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2964.description: Calculate the differences in codon usage fractions between two sequences, sets of sequences, codon usage tables etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3715.label: Metabolic labeling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3715.description: Labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 or N-15 enriched grown medium or feed.|This includes N-15 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using N-15 enriched grown medium or feed) and C-13 metabolic labeling (labeling all proteins and (possibly) all amino acids using C-13 enriched grown medium or feed).

http://edamontology.org/operation_2945.label: Analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2945.description: Apply analytical methods to existing data of a specific type.|This excludes non-analytical methods that read and write the same basic type of data (for that, see 'Data handling').

http://edamontology.org/operation_0277.label: Pathway or network comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_0277.description: Compare two or more biological pathways or networks.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0400.label: Protein pKa calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0400.description: Calculate pH-dependent properties from pKa calculations of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0397.label: Ramachandran plot validation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0397.description: Validate a Ramachandran plot of a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0404.label: Protein hydrogen exchange rate calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0404.description: Estimate hydrogen exchange rate of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3351.label: Molecular surface analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3351.description: Analyse the surface properties of proteins or other macromolecules, including surface accessible pockets, interior inaccessible cavities etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3695.label: Filtering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3695.description: Filter a set of files or data items according to some property.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3631.label: Peptide identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3631.description: Determination of peptide sequence from mass spectrum.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0249.label: Protein geometry calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0249.description: Calculate, visualise or analyse phi/psi angles of a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0338.label: Sequence database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_0338.description:
Search a sequence database by sequence comparison and retrieve similar sequences.

sequences matching a given sequence motif or pattern, such as a Prosite pattern or regular expression.|This excludes direct retrieval methods (e.g. the dbfetch program).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0465.label: siRNA binding specificity prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0465.description: Assess binding specificity of putative siRNA sequence(s), for example for a functional assay, typically with respect to designing specific siRNA sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0556.label: Phylogenetic sub/super tree detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0556.description: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to detect subtrees or supertrees.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3799.label: Quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3799.description: Counting and measuring experimentally determined observations into quantities.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3348.label: Sequence checksum generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3348.description: Generate a checksum of a molecular sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0408.label: Protein globularity prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0408.description: Predict the stability or globularity of a protein sequence, whether it is intrinsically unfolded etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0297.label: 3D profile generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0297.description: Generate some type of structural (3D) profile or template from a structure or structure alignment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0552.label: Phylogenetic tree bootstrapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0552.description: Apply bootstrapping or other measures to estimate confidence of a phylogenetic tree.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3194.label: Genome feature comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_3194.description: Compare the features of two genome sequences.|Genomic elements that might be compared include genes, indels, single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), retrotransposons, tandem repeats and so on.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0239.label: Sequence motif recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_0239.description: Find (scan for) known motifs, patterns and regular expressions in molecular sequence(s).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0409.label: Protein solubility prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0409.description: Predict the solubility or atomic solvation energy of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0368.label: Sequence masking
http://edamontology.org/operation_0368.description: Mask characters in a molecular sequence (replacing those characters with a mask character).|For example, SNPs or repeats in a DNA sequence might be masked.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3672.label: Gene functional annotation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3672.description: Annotate one or more sequences with functional information, such as cellular processes or metaobolic pathways, by reference to a controlled vocabulary - invariably the Gene Ontology (GO).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0391.label: Protein distance matrix calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0391.description: Calculate a matrix of distance between residues (for example the C-alpha atoms) in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2478.label: Nucleic acid sequence analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2478.description: Analyse a nucleic acid sequence (using methods that are only applicable to nucleic acid sequences).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0362.label: Genome annotation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0362.description: Annotate a genome sequence with terms from a controlled vocabulary.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0566.label: Sequence cluster visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0566.description: Visualise, format or render sequence clusters.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0469.label: Protein secondary structure prediction (turns)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0469.description: Predict turn structure (for example beta hairpin turns) of protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0235.label: Sequence ambiguity calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0235.description: Calculate sequence ambiguity, for example identity regions in protein or nucleotide sequences with many ambiguity codes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0557.label: Phylogenetic tree distances calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0557.description: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to calculate distances between trees.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3705.label: Isotope-coded protein label
http://edamontology.org/operation_3705.description: Chemical tagging free amino groups of intact proteins with stable isotopes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3662.label: Ab-initio gene prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3662.description: Prediction of genes or gene components from first principles, i.e. without reference to existing genes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0431.label: Restriction site recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_0431.description: Find and identify restriction enzyme cleavage sites (restriction sites) in (typically) DNA sequences, for example to generate a restriction map.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3557.label: Imputation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3557.description: Replace missing data with substituted values, usually by using some statistical or other mathematical approach.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3755.label: PTM localisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3755.description: Site localisation of post-translational modifications in peptide or protein mass spectra.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3502.label: Chemical similarity enrichment
http://edamontology.org/operation_3502.description: Analyse a dataset with respect to concepts from an ontology of chemical structure, leveraging chemical similarity information.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0240.label: Sequence motif comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_0240.description: Find motifs shared by molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0429.label: Quadruplex formation site detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0429.description: Detect quadruplex-forming motifs in nucleotide sequences.|Quadruplex (4-stranded) structures are formed by guanine-rich regions and are implicated in various important biological processes and as therapeutic targets.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3463.label: Gene expression correlation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3463.description: Analyse the correlation patterns among genes across across a variety of experiments, microarray samples etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0420.label: Protein-nucleic acid binding prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0420.description: Predict RNA and DNA-binding binding sites in protein sequences.|This includes methods that predict and optimise zinc finger protein domains for DNA/RNA binding (for example for transcription factors and nucleases).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0262.label: Nucleic acid property calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0262.description: Calculate or predict physical or chemical properties of nucleic acid molecules, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2942.label: Treemap visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2942.description: Visualise gene expression data after hierarchical clustering for representing hierarchical relationships.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0231.label: Sequence editing
http://edamontology.org/operation_0231.description: Edit or change a molecular sequence, either randomly or specifically.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0564.label: Sequence visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0564.description: Visualise, format or render a molecular sequence or sequences such as a sequence alignment, possibly with sequence features or properties shown.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0260.label: Sequence alignment conversion
http://edamontology.org/operation_0260.description: Convert a molecular sequence alignment from one type to another (for example amino acid to coding nucleotide sequence).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3639.label: iTRAQ
http://edamontology.org/operation_3639.description: Quantification analysis using the AB SCIEX iTRAQ isobaric labelling workflow, wherein 2-8 reporter ions are measured in MS2 spectra near 114 m/z.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3200.label: Community profiling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3200.description: Analyse DNA sequences in order to identify a DNA 'barcode'; marker genes or any short fragment(s) of DNA that are useful to diagnose the taxa of biological organisms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3203.label: Chromatogram visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3203.description: Visualise, format or render an image of a Chromatogram.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3478.label: Phylogenetic tree reconstruction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3478.description: Reconstructing the inner node labels of a phylogenetic tree from its leafes.|Note that this is somewhat different from simply analysing an existing tree or constructing a completely new one.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3224.label: Gene set testing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3224.description: Analyse gene expression patterns (typically from DNA microarray datasets) to identify sets of genes that are associated with a specific trait, condition, clinical outcome etc.|Gene sets can be defined beforehand by biological function, chromosome locations and so on.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3092.label: Protein feature detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_3092.description: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in proteins from analysing protein sequences or structures.|Features includes functional sites or regions, secondary structure, structural domains and so on. Methods might use fingerprints, motifs, profiles, hidden Markov models, sequence alignment etc to provide a mapping of a query protein sequence to a discriminatory element. This includes methods that search a secondary protein database (Prosite, Blocks, ProDom, Prints, Pfam etc.) to assign a protein sequence(s) to a known protein family or group.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3081.label: Sequence alignment editing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3081.description: Edit, convert or otherwise change a molecular sequence alignment, either randomly or specifically.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3793.label: Read summarisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3793.description: Counting and summarising the number of short sequence reads that map to genomic features.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2284.label: Nucleic acid density plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_2284.description: Calculate a density plot (of base composition) for a nucleotide sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3629.label: Deisotoping
http://edamontology.org/operation_3629.description: The removal of isotope peaks in a spectrum, to represent the fragment ion as one data point.|Deisotoping is commonly done to reduce complexity, and done in conjunction with the charge state deconvolution.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0336.label: Format validation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0336.description: Test and validate the format and content of a data file.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0289.label: Sequence distance matrix generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0289.description: Calculate a sequence distance matrix or otherwise estimate genetic distances between molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0445.label: Transcription factor binding site prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0445.description: Identify or predict transcription factor binding sites in DNA sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0550.label: DNA substitution modelling
http://edamontology.org/operation_0550.description: Identify a plausible model of DNA substitution that explains a molecular (DNA or protein) sequence alignment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2479.label: Protein sequence analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2479.description: Analyse a protein sequence (using methods that are only applicable to protein sequences).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0538.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (data centric)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0538.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree from a specific type of data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0365.label: Nucleic acid restriction digest
http://edamontology.org/operation_0365.description: Generate digest fragments for a nucleotide sequence containing restriction sites.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2499.label: Splicing model analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2499.description: Analyse, characterize and model alternative splicing events, typically by comparing multiple nucleic acid sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3080.label: Structure editing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3080.description: Edit, convert or otherwise change a  molecular tertiary structure, either randomly or specifically.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0488.label: Linkage disequilibrium calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0488.description: Calculate linkage disequilibrium; the non-random association of alleles or polymorphisms at two or more loci (not necessarily on the same chromosome).|Linkage disequilibrium is identified where a combination of alleles (or genetic markers) occurs more or less frequently in a population than expected by chance formation of haplotypes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3675.label: Variant filtering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3675.description: Variant filtering is used to eliminate false positive variants based for example on base calling quality, strand and position information, and mapping info.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0300.label: Sequence profile alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0300.description: Align molecular sequence(s) to sequence profile(s), or profiles to other profiles.  A profile typically represents a sequence alignment.|A sequence profile typically represents a sequence alignment. Methods might perform one-to-one, one-to-many or many-to-many comparisons.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2439.label: RNA secondary structure analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2439.description: Process (read and / or write) RNA secondary structure data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3432.label: Clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3432.description: Group together some data entities on the basis of similarities such that entities in the same group (cluster) are more similar to each other than to those in other groups (clusters).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3640.label: 18O labeling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3640.description: Quantification analysis using labeling based on 18O-enriched H2O.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0510.label: Global structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0510.description: Globally align (superimpose) two or more molecular tertiary structures.|Global alignment methods identify similarity across the entire structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0309.label: Microarray probe design
http://edamontology.org/operation_0309.description: Predict and/or optimize oligonucleotide probes for DNA microarrays, for example for transcription profiling of genes, or for genomes and gene families.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0380.label: Repeat sequence organisation analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0380.description: Analyse repeat sequence organisation such as periodicity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2575.label: Protein binding site prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_2575.description: Identify or predict catalytic residues, active sites or other ligand-binding sites in protein sequences or structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3095.label: Nucleic acid design
http://edamontology.org/operation_3095.description: Design (or predict) nucleic acid sequences with specific chemical or physical properties.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0394.label: Hydrogen bond calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0394.description: Identify potential hydrogen bonds between amino acids and other groups.|The output might include the atoms involved in the bond, bond geometric parameters and bond enthalpy.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3762.label: Service composition
http://edamontology.org/operation_3762.description: An operation supporting the aggregation of other services (at least two) into a funtional unit, for the automation of some task.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3431.label: Deposition
http://edamontology.org/operation_3431.description: Deposit some data in a database or some other type of repository or software system.|For non-analytical operations, see the 'Processing' branch.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0477.label: Protein modelling
http://edamontology.org/operation_0477.description: Build a three-dimensional protein model based on known (for example homologs) structures.|The model might be of a whole, part or aspect of protein structure. Molecular modelling methods might use sequence-structure alignment, structural templates, molecular dynamics, energy minimisation etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3445.label: Diffraction data analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3445.description: Analysis of data from a diffraction experiment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3465.label: Correlation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3465.description: Identify a correlation, i.e. a statistical relationship between two random variables or two sets of data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0323.label: Phylogenetic tree generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0323.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree.|Phylogenetic trees are usually constructed from a set of sequences from which an alignment (or data matrix) is calculated.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0369.label: Sequence cutting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0369.description: Cut (remove) characters or a region from a molecular sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3227.label: Variant calling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3227.description: Identify and map genomic alterations, including single nucleotide polymorphisms, short indels and structural variants, in a genome sequence.|Somatic variant calling is the detection of variations established in somatic cells and hence not inherited as a germ line variant.|Variant detection|Methods often utilise a database of aligned reads.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3703.label: Reference identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3703.description: Identification of the best reference for mapping for a specific dataset from a list of potential references, when performing genetic variation analysis.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1839.label: Salt bridge calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_1839.description: Calculate (and possibly score) salt bridges in a protein structure.|Salt bridges are interactions between oppositely charged atoms in different residues. The output might include the inter-atomic distance.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3198.label: Read mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_3198.description: Align short oligonucleotide sequences (reads) to a larger (genomic) sequence.|The purpose of read mapping is to identify the location of sequenced fragments within a reference genome and assumes that there is, in fact, at least local similarity between the fragment and reference sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0270.label: Transmembrane protein analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0270.description: Analyse transmembrane protein(s), typically by processing sequence and / or structural data, and write an informative report for example about the protein and its transmembrane domains / regions.|Use this (or child) concept for analysis of transmembrane domains (buried and exposed faces), transmembrane helices, helix topology, orientation, inter-helical contacts, membrane dipping (re-entrant) loops and other secondary structure etc. Methods might use pattern discovery, hidden Markov models, sequence alignment, structural profiles, amino acid property analysis, comparison to known domains or some combination (hybrid methods).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3800.label: RNA-Seq quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3800.description: Quantification of data arising from RNA-Seq high-throughput sequencing, typically the quantification of transcript abundances durnig transcriptome analysis in a gene expression study.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3801.label: Spectral library search
