http://edamontology.org/operation_3801.description: Match experimentally measured mass spectrum to a spectrum in a spectral library or database.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0554.label: Phylogenetic tree analysis (natural selection)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0554.description: Analyse a phylogenetic tree to identify allele frequency distribution and change that is subject to evolutionary pressures (natural selection, genetic drift, mutation and gene flow). Identify type of natural selection (such as stabilizing, balancing or disruptive).|Stabilizing/purifying (directional) selection favors a single phenotype and tends to decrease genetic diversity as a population stabilizes on a particular trait, selecting out trait extremes or deleterious mutations. In contrast, balancing selection maintain genetic polymorphisms (or multiple alleles), whereas disruptive (or diversifying) selection favors individuals at both extremes of a trait.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2574.label: Protein hydropathy calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2574.description: Analyse the hydrophobic, hydrophilic or charge properties of a protein (from analysis of sequence or structural information).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3795.label: In vitro selection
http://edamontology.org/operation_3795.description: A technique whereby molecules with desired properties and function are isolated from libraries of random molecules, through iterative cycles of selection, amplification, and mutagenesis.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2474.label: Protein architecture comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_2474.description: Compare the architecture of two or more protein structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0551.label: Phylogenetic tree analysis (shape)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0551.description: Analyse the shape (topology) of a phylogenetic tree.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3258.label: Transcriptome assembly
http://edamontology.org/operation_3258.description: Infer a transcriptome sequence by analysis of short sequence reads.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0233.label: Sequence conversion
http://edamontology.org/operation_0233.description: Convert a molecular sequence from one type to another.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0418.label: Protein signal peptide detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0418.description: Detect or predict signal peptides and signal peptide cleavage sites in protein sequences.|Methods might use sequence motifs and features, amino acid composition, profiles, machine-learned classifiers, etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3704.label: Ion counting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3704.description: Label-free quantification by integration of ion current (ion counting).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3458.label: Single particle alignment and classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3458.description: Compare (align and classify) multiple particle images from a micrograph in order to produce a representative image of the particle. |A micrograph can include particles in multiple different orientations and/or conformations. Particles are compared and organised into sets based on their similarity. Typically iterations of classification and alignment and are performed to optimise the final 3D EM map.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0570.label: Structure visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0570.description: Visualise or render molecular structure, for example a high-quality static picture or animation.  This includes secondary structure such as knots, pseudoknots etc. as well as tertiary and quaternary structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0553.label: Phylogenetic tree analysis (gene family prediction)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0553.description: Predict families of genes and gene function based on their position in a phylogenetic tree.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0346.label: Sequence similarity search
http://edamontology.org/operation_0346.description: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences that are similar to a query sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3645.label: PTM identification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3645.description: Identification of post-translational modifications (PTMs) of peptides/proteins in mass spectrum.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0337.label: Visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0337.description: Visualise, plot or render (graphically) biomolecular data such as molecular sequences or structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3207.label: Gene methylation analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3207.description: Analysing the DNA methylation of specific genes or regions of interest.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0495.label: Local alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0495.description: Locally align two or more molecular sequences.|Local alignment methods identify regions of local similarity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3552.label: Microscope image visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3552.description: Visualise images resulting from various types of microscopy.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3453.label: Diffraction data integration
http://edamontology.org/operation_3453.description: The evaluation of diffraction intensities and integration of diffraction maxima from a diffraction experiment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3197.label: Genetic variation analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3197.description: Analyse a genetic variation, for example to annotate its location, alleles, classification, and effects on individual transcripts predicted for a gene model.|Genetic variation annotation provides contextual interpretation of coding SNP consequences in transcripts. It allows comparisons to be made between variation data in different populations or strains for the same transcript.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3184.label: Sequence assembly visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3184.description: Render and visualise a DNA sequence assembly.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0436.label: Coding region prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0436.description: Predict protein-coding regions (CDS or exon) or open reading frames in nucleotide sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3217.label: Scaffold gap completion
http://edamontology.org/operation_3217.description: Fill the gaps in a sequence assembly (scaffold) by merging in additional sequences.|Different techniques are used to generate gap sequences to connect contigs, depending on the size of the gap. For small (5-20kb) gaps, PCR amplification and sequencing is used.  For large (>20kb) gaps, fragments are cloned (e.g. in BAC (Bacterial artificial chromosomes) vectors) and then sequenced.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1850.label: Protein cysteine and disulfide bond assignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_1850.description: Assign cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3446.label: Cell migration analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3446.description: Analysis of cell migration images in order to study cell migration, typically in order to study the processes that play a role in the disease progression.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0470.label: Protein secondary structure prediction (coils)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0470.description: Predict open coils, non-regular secondary structure and intrinsically disordered / unstructured regions of protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2939.label: Principal component plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_2939.description: Visualize the results of a principal component analysis (orthogonal data transformation).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0438.label: Transcriptional regulatory element prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0438.description: Identify or predict transcriptional regulatory motifs, patterns, elements or regions in DNA sequences.|This includes promoters, enhancers, silencers and boundary elements / insulators, regulatory protein or transcription factor binding sites etc. Methods might be specific to a particular genome and use motifs, word-based / grammatical methods, position-specific frequency matrices, discriminative pattern analysis etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3659.label: Regression analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3659.description: A statistical calculation to estimate the relationships among variables.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0479.label: Protein modelling (backbone)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0479.description: Model protein backbone conformation.|Methods might require a preliminary C(alpha) trace.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2998.label: Nucleic acid comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_2998.description: Compare two or more nucleic acids to identify similarities.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0389.label: Protein-nucleic acid binding site analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0389.description: Analyse RNA or DNA-binding sites in protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2421.label: Database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_2421.description: Search a database (or other data resource) with a supplied query and retrieve entries (or parts of entries) that are similar to the query.|Typically the query is compared to each entry and high scoring matches (hits) are returned. For example, a BLAST search of a sequence database.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3646.label: Peptide database search
http://edamontology.org/operation_3646.description: Determination of best matches between MS/MS spectrum and a database of protein or nucleic acid sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3480.label: Probabilistic data generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3480.description: Generate some data from a choosen probibalistic model, possibly to evaluate algorithms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3434.label: Conversion
http://edamontology.org/operation_3434.description: Convert a data set from one form to another.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0363.label: Nucleic acid sequence reverse and complement
http://edamontology.org/operation_0363.description: Generate the reverse and / or complement of a nucleotide sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0313.label: Gene expression clustering
http://edamontology.org/operation_0313.description: Perform cluster analysis of gene expression data to identify groups with similar gene-expression profiles, for example by clustering.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0305.label: Literature search
http://edamontology.org/operation_0305.description: Query scientific literature, in search for articles, article data, concepts, named entities, or for statistics.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0232.label: Sequence merging
http://edamontology.org/operation_0232.description: Merge two or more (typically overlapping) molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3634.label: Label-free quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3634.description: Quantification without the use of chemical tags.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3694.label: Mass spectrum visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3694.description: Visualise, format or render a mass spectrum.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0310.label: Sequence assembly
http://edamontology.org/operation_0310.description: Combine (align and merge) overlapping fragments of a DNA sequence to reconstruct the original sequence.|For example, assemble overlapping reads from paired-end sequencers into contigs (a contiguous sequence corresponding to read overlaps). Or assemble contigs, for example ESTs and genomic DNA fragments, depending on the detected fragment overlaps.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2464.label: Protein-protein interaction prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_2464.description: Identify or predict protein-protein interactions, interfaces, binding sites etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3211.label: Genome indexing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3211.description: Generate an index of a genome sequence.|Many sequence alignment tasks involving many or very large sequences rely on a precomputed index of the sequence to accelerate the alignment.  The Burrows-Wheeler Transform (BWT) is a permutation of the genome based on a suffix array algorithm.  A suffix array consists of the lexicographically sorted list of suffixes of a genome.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0361.label: Sequence annotation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0361.description: Annotate a molecular sequence record with terms from a controlled vocabulary.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3439.label: Pathway or network prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3439.description: Predict a molecular pathway or network.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3553.label: Image annotation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3553.description: Annotate an image of some sort, typically with terms from a controlled vocabulary.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0319.label: Protein secondary structure assignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0319.description: Assign secondary structure from protein coordinate or experimental data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0464.label: tRNA gene prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0464.description: Identify or predict tRNA genes in genomic sequences (tRNA).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3461.label: Virulence prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3461.description: The prediction of the degree of pathogenicity of a microorganism from analysis of molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3638.label: SILAC
http://edamontology.org/operation_3638.description: Quantification analysis using stable isotope labeling by amino acids in cell culture.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3206.label: Whole genome methylation analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3206.description: Measure the overall level of methyl cytosines in a genome from analysis of experimental data, typically from chromatographic methods and methyl accepting capacity assay.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0403.label: Protein isoelectric point calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0403.description: Calculate isoelectric point of a protein sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0335.label: Formatting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0335.description: Reformat a file of data (or equivalent entity in memory).

http://edamontology.org/operation_2492.label: Protein interaction prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_2492.description: Predict the interactions of proteins with other molecules.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0259.label: Sequence alignment comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_0259.description: Compare (typically by aligning) two molecular sequence alignments.|See also 'Sequence profile alignment'.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0448.label: Sequence alignment analysis (conservation)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0448.description: Analyse character conservation in a molecular sequence alignment, for example to derive a consensus sequence.|Use this concept for methods that calculate substitution rates, estimate relative site variability, identify sites with biased properties, derive a consensus sequence, or identify highly conserved or very poorly conserved sites, regions, blocks etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3663.label: Homology-based gene prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3663.description: Prediction of genes or gene components by reference to homologous genes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3798.label: Read binning
http://edamontology.org/operation_3798.description: An operation which groups reads or contigs and assigns them to operational taxonomic units.|Binning methods use one or a combination of compositional features or sequence similarity.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0452.label: Indel detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0452.description: Identify insertion, deletion and duplication events from a sequence alignment.|Tools might use a genetic algorithm, quartet-mapping, bootscanning, graphical methods, random forest model and so on.

synonyms: Phylogenetic tree construction (from continuous quantitative characters)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0541.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from continuous quantitative characters)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0541.description: Phylogenetic tree construction from continuous quantitative character data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3731.label: Sample comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_3731.description: The comparison of samples from a metagenomics study, for example, by comparison of metagenome shotgun reads or assembled contig sequences, by comparison of functional profiles, or some other method.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0482.label: Protein-ligand docking
http://edamontology.org/operation_0482.description: Model protein-ligand (for example protein-peptide) binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.|Methods aim to predict the position and orientation of a ligand bound to a protein receptor or enzyme.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3454.label: Phasing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3454.description: Phase a macromolecular crystal structure, for example by using molecular replacement or experimental phasing methods.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2403.label: Sequence analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2403.description: Analyse one or more known molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2481.label: Nucleic acid structure analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2481.description: Analyse nucleic acid tertiary structural data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3802.label: Sorting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3802.description: Sort a set of files or data items according to some property.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0435.label: Operon prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0435.description: Find operons (operators, promoters and genes) in bacteria genes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0227.label: Indexing
http://edamontology.org/operation_0227.description: Generate an index of (typically a file of) biological data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0238.label: Sequence motif discovery
http://edamontology.org/operation_0238.description: Discover new motifs or conserved patterns in sequences or sequence alignments (de-novo discovery).|Motifs and patterns might be conserved or over-represented (occur with improbable frequency).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0279.label: Nucleic acid folding analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0279.description: Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data.  For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2489.label: Protein subcellular localisation prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_2489.description: Predict the subcellular localisation of a protein sequence.|The prediction might include subcellular localisation (nuclear, cytoplasmic, mitochondrial, chloroplast, plastid, membrane etc) or export (extracellular proteins) of a protein.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0237.label: Repeat sequence analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0237.description: Find and/or analyse repeat sequences in (typically nucleotide) sequences.|Repeat sequences include tandem repeats, inverted or palindromic repeats, DNA microsatellites (Simple Sequence Repeats or SSRs), interspersed repeats, maximal duplications and reverse, complemented and reverse complemented repeats etc. Repeat units can be exact or imperfect, in tandem or dispersed, of specified or unspecified length.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0457.label: Nucleic acid stitch profile plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0457.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA stitch profile.|A stitch profile represents the alternative conformations that partly melted DNA can adopt in a temperature range.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0449.label: Sequence alignment analysis (site correlation)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0449.description: Analyse correlations between sites in a molecular sequence alignment.|This is typically done to identify possible covarying positions and predict contacts or structural constraints in protein structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0296.label: Sequence profile generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0296.description: Generate some type of sequence profile (for example a hidden Markov model) from a sequence alignment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3359.label: Splitting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3359.description: Split a file containing multiple data items into many files, each containing one item

http://edamontology.org/operation_0246.label: Protein domain recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_0246.description: Identify structural domains in a protein structure from first principles (for example calculations on structural compactness).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3644.label: de Novo sequencing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3644.description: Analytical process that derives a peptide’s amino acid sequence from its tandem mass spectrum (MS/MS) without the assistance of a sequence database.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0484.label: SNP detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0484.description: Find single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) - single nucleotide change in base positions - between sequences. Typically done for sequences from a high-throughput sequencing experiment that differ from a reference genome and which might, especially by reference to population frequency or functional data, indicate a polymorphism.|This includes functional SNPs for large-scale genotyping purposes, disease-associated non-synonymous SNPs etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3472.label: k-mer counting
http://edamontology.org/operation_3472.description: Count k-mers (substrings of length k) in DNA sequence data.|k-mer counting is used in genome and transcriptome assembly, metagenomic sequencing, and for error correction of sequence reads.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0392.label: Protein contact map calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0392.description: Calculate a residue contact map (typically all-versus-all inter-residue contacts) for a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3661.label: SNP annotation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3661.description: Predict the effect or function of an individual single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0250.label: Protein property calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0250.description: Extract, calculate or predict non-positional (physical or chemical) properties of a protein, including any non-positional properties of the molecular sequence, from processing a protein sequence or 3D structure.|This includes methods to render and visualise the properties of a protein sequence, and a residue-level search for properties such as solvent accessibility, hydropathy, secondary structure, ligand-binding etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3282.label: ID mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_3282.description: Map data identifiers to one another for example to establish a link between two biological databases for the purposes of data integration.|The mapping can be achieved by comparing identifier values or some other means, e.g. exact matches to a provided sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0483.label: Structured RNA prediction and optimisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0483.description: Predict or optimise RNA sequences (sequence pools) with likely secondary and tertiary structure for in vitro selection.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3267.label: Sequence coordinate conversion
http://edamontology.org/operation_3267.description: Convert one set of sequence coordinates to another, e.g. convert coordinates of one assembly to another, cDNA to genomic, CDS to genomic, protein translation to genomic etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1777.label: Protein function prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_1777.description: Predict general functional properties of a protein.|For functional properties that can be mapped to a sequence, use 'Sequence feature detection (protein)' instead.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0444.label: S/MAR prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0444.description: Identify matrix/scaffold attachment regions (MARs/SARs) in DNA sequences.|MAR/SAR sites often flank a gene or gene cluster and are found nearby cis-regulatory sequences. They might contribute to transcription regulation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3635.label: Labeled quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3635.description: Quantification based on the use of chemical tags.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3208.label: Genome visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3208.description: Visualise, format or render a nucleic acid sequence that is part of (and in context of) a complete genome sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0292.label: Sequence alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0292.description: Align (identify equivalent sites within) molecular sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3218.label: Sequencing quality control
http://edamontology.org/operation_3218.description: Raw sequence data quality control.|Analyse raw sequence data from a sequencing pipeline and identify (and possiby fix) problems.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0415.label: Nucleic acid feature detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0415.description: Predict, recognise and identify features in nucleotide sequences such as functional sites or regions, typically by scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.|Methods typically involve scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3565.label: RNA-seq time series data analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3565.description: Analyze time series data from an RNA-seq experiment.

synonyms: PCR primer design (for large scale sequencing)
PCR primer design (for gene transcription profiling)
PCR primer design (based on gene structure)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0308.label: PCR primer design
http://edamontology.org/operation_0308.description: Design or predict oligonucleotide primers for PCR and DNA amplification etc.|Primer design involves predicting or selecting primers that are specific to a provided PCR template. Primers can be designed with certain properties such as size of product desired, primer size etc. The output might be a minimal or overlapping primer set.|This includes predicting primers based on gene structure, promoters, exon-exon junctions, predicting primers that are conserved across multiple genomes or species, primers for for gene transcription profiling,  for genotyping polymorphisms, for example single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs),  for large scale sequencing, or for methylation PCRs.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0324.label: Phylogenetic tree analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0324.description: Analyse an existing phylogenetic tree or trees, typically to detect features or make predictions.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0322.label: Molecular model refinement
http://edamontology.org/operation_0322.description: Refine (after evaluation) a model of a molecular structure (typically a protein structure) to reduce steric clashes, volume irregularities etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3186.label: Bisulfite mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_3186.description: The mapping of methylation sites in a DNA (genome) sequence.|Bisulfite mapping follows high-throughput sequencing of DNA which has undergone bisulfite treatment followed by PCR amplification; unmethylated cytosines are specifically converted to thymine, allowing the methylation status of cytosine in the DNA to be detected.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0471.label: Disulfide bond prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0471.description: Predict cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0349.label: Sequence database search (by property)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0349.description: Search a sequence database and retrieve sequences with a specified property, typically a physicochemical or compositional property.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3230.label: Read depth analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3230.description: Analyse mapping density (read depth) of (typically) short reads from sequencing platforms, for example, to detect deletions and duplications.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0372.label: DNA transcription
http://edamontology.org/operation_0372.description: Transcribe a nucleotide sequence into mRNA sequence(s).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0460.label: Nucleic acid temperature profile plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0460.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA temperature profile.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0384.label: Accessible surface calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0384.description: Calculate solvent accessible or buried surface areas in protein or other molecular structures.|Solvent accessibility might be calculated for the backbone, sidechain and total (backbone plus sidechain).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3187.label: Sequence contamination filtering
http://edamontology.org/operation_3187.description: Identify and filter a (typically large) sequence data set to remove sequences from contaminants in the sample that was sequenced.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0524.label: De-novo assembly
http://edamontology.org/operation_0524.description: Sequence assembly by combining fragments without the aid of a reference sequence or genome.|De-novo assemblers are much slower and more memory intensive than mapping assemblers.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2239.label: 3D-1D scoring matrix generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2239.description: Calculate a 3D-1D scoring matrix from analysis of protein sequence and structural data.|A 3D-1D scoring matrix scores the probability of amino acids occurring in different structural environments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0288.label: Sequence word comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_0288.description: Find exact character or word matches between molecular sequences without full sequence alignment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0264.label: Splice transcript prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0264.description: Predict splicing alternatives or transcript isoforms from analysis of sequence data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3350.label: Protein quaternary structure prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3350.description: Predict the structure of a multi-subunit protein and particularly how the subunits fit together.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0468.label: Protein secondary structure prediction (helices)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0468.description: Predict helical secondary structure of protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0422.label: Protein cleavage site prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0422.description: Detect or predict cleavage sites (enzymatic or chemical) in protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0416.label: Epitope mapping
http://edamontology.org/operation_0416.description: Predict antigenic determinant sites (epitopes) in protein sequences.|Epitope mapping is commonly done during vaccine design.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0325.label: Phylogenetic tree comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_0325.description: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees.|For example, to produce a consensus tree, subtrees, supertrees, calculate distances between trees or test topological similarity between trees (e.g. a congruence index) etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0320.label: Protein structure assignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0320.description: Assign a protein tertiary structure (3D coordinates), or other aspects of protein structure, from raw experimental data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3437.label: Article comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_3437.description: Compare two or more scientific articles.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0489.label: Genetic code prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0489.description: Predict genetic code from analysis of codon usage data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0463.label: microRNA detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0463.description: Identify or predict microRNA sequences (miRNA) and precursors or microRNA targets / binding sites in a DNA sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3460.label: Taxonomic classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3460.description: Classifiication (typically of molecular sequences) by assignment to some taxonomic hierarchy.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2121.label: Sequence file editing
http://edamontology.org/operation_2121.description: Perform basic (non-analytical) operations on a report or file of sequences (which might include features), such as file concatenation, removal or ordering of sequences, creation of subset or a new file of sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1812.label: Loading
http://edamontology.org/operation_1812.description: Prepare or load a user-specified data file so that it is available for use.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2497.label: Pathway or network analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2497.description: Generate, process or analyse a biological pathway or network.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0523.label: Mapping assembly
http://edamontology.org/operation_0523.description: Sequence assembly by combining fragments using an existing backbone sequence, typically a reference genome.|The final sequence will resemble the backbone sequence. Mapping assemblers are usually much faster and less memory intensive than de-novo assemblers.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0004.label: Operation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0004.description: A function that processes a set of inputs and results in a set of outputs, or associates arguments (inputs) with values (outputs).|Special cases are: a) An operation that consumes no input (has no input arguments). Such operation is either a constant function, or an operation depending only on the underlying state. b) An operation that may modify the underlying state but has no output. c) The singular-case operation with no input or output, that still may modify the underlying state.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0269.label: Transmembrane protein prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0269.description: Predict and/or classify transmembrane proteins or transmembrane (helical) domains or regions in protein sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0481.label: Protein modelling (loops)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0481.description: Model loop conformation in protein structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3677.label: Differential binding analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3677.description: Differential binding analysis identifies binding sites in nucleic acid sequences that are statistically significantly differentially bound between sample groups.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3561.label: Database comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_3561.description: Compare the models or schemas used by two or more databases, or any other general comparison of databases rather than a detailed comparison of the entries themselves.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0555.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (consensus)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0555.description: Compare two or more phylogenetic trees to produce a consensus tree.|Methods typically test for topological similarity between trees using for example a congruence index.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2943.label: Box-Whisker plot plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_2943.description: Generate a box plot, i.e. a depiction of groups of numerical data through their quartiles.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3745.label: Ancestral reconstruction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3745.description: The extrapolation of empirical characteristics of individuals or populations, backwards in time, to their common ancestors.|Ancestral reconstruction is often used to recover possible ancestral character states of ancient, extinct organisms.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0546.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (minimum distance methods)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0546.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree by computing (or using precomputed) distances between sequences and searching for the tree with minimal discrepancies between pairwise distances.|This includes neighbor joining (NJ) clustering method.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2996.label: Structure classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_2996.description: Assign molecular structure(s) to a group or category.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2414.label: Protein function analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2414.description: Analyse protein function, typically by processing protein sequence and/or structural data, and generate an informative report.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3642.label: Dimethyl
http://edamontology.org/operation_3642.description: Quantification analysis using chemical labeling by stable isotope dimethylation

http://edamontology.org/operation_3436.label: Aggregation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3436.description: Combine multiple files or data items into a single file or object.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0226.label: Annotation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0226.description: Annotate an entity (typically a biological or biomedical database entity) with terms from a controlled vocabulary.|This is a broad concept and is used a placeholder for other, more specific concepts.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0407.label: Protein hydrophobic moment plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0407.description: Calculate the hydrophobic moment of a peptide sequence and recognize amphiphilicity.|Hydrophobic moment is a peptides hydrophobicity measured for different angles of rotation.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3456.label: Rigid body refinement
http://edamontology.org/operation_3456.description: A method used to refine a structure by moving the whole molecule or parts of it as a rigid unit, rather than moving individual atoms.|Rigid body refinement usually follows molecular replacement in the assignment of a structure from diffraction data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0294.label: Structure-based sequence alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0294.description: Align molecular sequences using sequence and structural information.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3096.label: Editing
http://edamontology.org/operation_3096.description: Edit a data entity, either randomly or specifically.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0451.label: Recombination detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0451.description: Detect recombination (hotspots and coldspots) and identify recombination breakpoints in a sequence alignment.|Tools might use a genetic algorithm, quartet-mapping, bootscanning, graphical methods, random forest model and so on.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0575.label: Restriction map drawing
http://edamontology.org/operation_0575.description: Draw or visualise restriction maps in DNA sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2950.label: Residue distance calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2950.description: Calculate contacts between residues, or between residues and other groups, in a protein structure, on the basis of distance calculations.|This includes identifying HET groups, which usually correspond to ligands, lipids, but might also (not consistently) include groups that are attached to amino acids. Each HET group is supposed to have a unique three letter code and a unique name which might be given in the output.  It can also include calculation of symmetry contacts, i.e. a contact between two atoms in different asymmetric unit.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3221.label: Species frequency estimation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3221.description: Estimate the frequencies of different species from analysis of the molecular sequences, typically of DNA recovered from environmental samples.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0367.label: Sequence mutation and randomisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0367.description: Mutate a molecular sequence a specified amount or shuffle it to produce a randomised sequence with the same overall composition.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0290.label: Sequence redundancy removal
http://edamontology.org/operation_0290.description: Compare two or more molecular sequences, identify and remove redundant sequences based on some criteria.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3196.label: Genotyping
http://edamontology.org/operation_3196.description: Analyse DNA sequence data to identify differences between the genetic composition (genotype) of an individual compared to other individual's or a reference sequence.|Methods might consider cytogenetic analyses, copy number polymorphism (and calculate copy number calls for copy-number variation(CNV) regions), single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP), , rare copy number variation (CNV) identification, loss of heterozygosity data and so on.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0447.label: Sequence alignment validation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0447.description: Evaluate molecular sequence alignment accuracy.|Evaluation might be purely sequence-based or use structural information.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0283.label: Linkage analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0283.description: Analyse genetic linkage.|For example, estimate how close two genes are on a chromosome by calculating how often they are transmitted together to an offspring, ascertain whether two genes are linked and parental linkage, calculate linkage map distance etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3636.label: MRM/SRM
http://edamontology.org/operation_3636.description: Quantification by Selected/multiple Reaction Monitoring workflow (XIC quantitation of precursor / fragment mass pair).

http://edamontology.org/operation_3630.label: Protein quantification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3630.description: Technique for determining the amount of proteins in a sample.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3664.label: Statistical modelling
http://edamontology.org/operation_3664.description: Construction of a statistical model, or a set of assumptions around some observed data, usually by describing a set of probability distributions which approximate the distribution of data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3214.label: Spectral analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3214.description: Analyse one or more spectra from mass spectrometry (or other) experiments.

synonyms: Phylogenetic tree-based multiple sequence alignment construction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0499.label: Tree-based sequence alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0499.description: Align multiple sequences using relative gap costs calculated from neighbors in a supplied phylogenetic tree.|This is supposed to give a more biologically meaningful alignment than standard alignments.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0504.label: Multiple structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0504.description: Align (superimpose) more than two molecular tertiary structures.|This includes methods that use an existing alignment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3744.label: Multiple sample visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3744.description: Visualise, format or render data arising from an analysis of multiple samples from a metagenomics/community experiment.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3225.label: Variant classification
http://edamontology.org/operation_3225.description: Classify variants based on their potential effect on genes, especially functional effects on the expressed proteins.|Variants are typically classified by their position (intronic, exonic, etc.) in a gene transcript and (for variants in coding exons) by their effect on the protein sequence (synonymous, non-synonymous, frameshifting, etc.)

http://edamontology.org/operation_0539.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (method centric)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0539.description: Construct a phylogenetic tree using a specific method.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0371.label: DNA translation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0371.description: Translate a DNA sequence into protein.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2415.label: Protein folding analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_2415.description: Analyse, simulate or predict protein folding, typically by processing sequence and / or structural data.  For example, predict sites of nucleation or stabilisation key to protein folding.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0265.label: Frameshift detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_0265.description: Detect frameshifts in DNA sequences, including frameshift sites and signals, and frameshift errors from sequencing projects.|Methods include sequence alignment (if related sequences are available) and word-based sequence comparison.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2409.label: Data handling
http://edamontology.org/operation_2409.description: Basic (non-analytical) operations of some data, either a file or equivalent entity in memory, such that the same basic type of data is consumed as input and generated as output.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1831.label: Metal-bound cysteine detection
http://edamontology.org/operation_1831.description: Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0386.label: Protein dipole moment calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0386.description: Calculate whether a protein structure has an unusually large net charge (dipole moment).

http://edamontology.org/operation_0276.label: Protein interaction network analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_0276.description: Analyse a network of protein interactions.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3482.label: Antimicrobial resistance prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_3482.description: Identify or predict causes for antibiotic resistance from molecular sequence analysis.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0393.label: Residue cluster calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0393.description: Calculate clusters of contacting residues in protein structures.|This includes for example clusters of hydrophobic or charged residues, or clusters of contacting residues which have a key structural or functional role.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0314.label: Gene expression profiling
http://edamontology.org/operation_0314.description: The measurement of the gene expression of multiple genes in a cell, tissue, sample etc., in order to get an impression of biological function.|Metagenomic inference is the profiling of phylogenetic marker genes in order to predict metagenome function.|Gene expression profiling generates some sort of gene expression profile, for example from microarray data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2937.label: Proximity map plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_2937.description: Generate a plot of distances (distance or correlation matrix) between expression values.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0234.label: Sequence complexity calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0234.description: Calculate sequence complexity, for example to find low-complexity regions in sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3564.label: Chemical redundancy removal
http://edamontology.org/operation_3564.description: Identify and remove redudancy from a set of small molecule structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0267.label: Protein secondary structure prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0267.description: Predict secondary structure of protein sequences.|Methods might use amino acid composition, local sequence information, multiple sequence alignments, physicochemical features, estimated energy content, statistical algorithms, hidden Markov models, support vector machines, kernel machines, neural networks etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3182.label: Genome alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_3182.description: Align two or more (tpyically huge) molecular sequences that represent genomes.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0230.label: Sequence generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0230.description: Generate a molecular sequence by some means.

http://edamontology.org/operation_1816.label: Surface rendering
http://edamontology.org/operation_1816.description: Calculate the positions of dots that are homogeneously distributed over the surface of a molecule.|A dot has three coordinates (x,y,z) and (typically) a color.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0461.label: Nucleic acid curvature calculation
http://edamontology.org/operation_0461.description: Calculate curvature and flexibility / stiffness of a nucleotide sequence.|This includes properties such as.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0458.label: Nucleic acid melting curve plotting
http://edamontology.org/operation_0458.description: Calculate and plot a DNA or DNA/RNA melting curve.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2241.label: Transmembrane protein visualisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_2241.description: Visualise transmembrane proteins, typically the transmembrane regions within a sequence.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0360.label: Structural similarity search
http://edamontology.org/operation_0360.description: Search a database of molecular structure and retrieve structures that are similar to a query structure.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0544.label: Phylogenetic species tree construction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0544.description: Construct a phylogenetic species tree, for example, from a genome-wide sequence comparison.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3481.label: Probabilistic sequence generation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3481.description: Generate sequences from some probabilistic model, e.g. a model that simulates evolution.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3443.label: Image analysis
http://edamontology.org/operation_3443.description: The analysis of a image (typically a digital image) of some type in order to extract information from it.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0427.label: Transposon prediction
http://edamontology.org/operation_0427.description: Detect or predict transposons, retrotransposons / retrotransposition signatures etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0503.label: Pairwise structure alignment
http://edamontology.org/operation_0503.description: Align (superimpose) exactly two molecular tertiary structures.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0245.label: Protein structural motif recognition
http://edamontology.org/operation_0245.description: Identify or screen for 3D structural motifs in protein structure(s).|This includes conserved substructures and conserved geometry, such as spatial arrangement of secondary structure or protein backbone. Methods might use structure alignment, structural templates, searches for similar electrostatic potential and molecular surface shape, surface-mapping of phylogenetic information etc.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0543.label: Phylogenetic tree generation (from polymorphism data)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0543.description: Phylogenetic tree construction from polymorphism data including microsatellites, RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphisms), RAPD (random-amplified polymorphic DNA) and AFLP (amplified fragment length polymorphisms) data.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2430.label: Design
http://edamontology.org/operation_2430.description: Design a biological entity (typically a molecular sequence or structure) with specific properties.

http://edamontology.org/operation_0480.label: Protein modelling (side chains)
http://edamontology.org/operation_0480.description: Model, analyse or edit amino acid side chain conformation in protein structure, optimize side-chain packing, hydrogen bonding etc.|Methods might use a residue rotamer library.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3192.label: Sequence trimming
http://edamontology.org/operation_3192.description:
Cut (remove) the end from a molecular sequence.|This includes



ennd trimming

Trim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove misleading ends.

For example trim polyA tails, introns and primer sequence flanking the sequence of amplified exons, or other unwanted sequence.



trimming to a reference sequence, 

Trim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove the sequence ends that extend beyond an assembled reference sequence.



vector trimming

Trim sequences (typically from an automated DNA sequencer) to remove sequence-specific end regions, typically contamination from vector sequences.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3229.label: Exome assembly
http://edamontology.org/operation_3229.description: Analyse sequencing data from experiments aiming to selectively sequence the coding regions of the genome.

http://edamontology.org/operation_3226.label: Variant prioritisation
http://edamontology.org/operation_3226.description: Identify biologically interesting variants by prioritizing individual variants, for example, homozygous variants absent in control genomes.|Variant prioritisation can be used for example to produce a list of variants responsible for 'knocking out' genes in specific genomes. Methods amino acid substitution, aggregative approaches, probabilistic approach, inheritance and unified likelihood-frameworks.

http://edamontology.org/operation_2483.label: Structure comparison
http://edamontology.org/operation_2483.description: Compare two or more molecular tertiary structures.
